Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Electrocatalytic Hydrogenation of Biorenewable Feedstock to Fuels and Chemicals

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Jean-Philippe Tessonnier
Proposal Number: 1512126


Plant biomass represents an abundant, cheap, and renewable feedstock for the production of liquid transportation fuels and chemicals. The highly selective chemical conversion of biomass to specific biofuels and chemicals requires catalysts. However, to be cost-effective and truly sustainable, biomass conversion processes that use catalysts based on materials abundant in the Earths crust must be developed. Furthermore, if these new catalysts can be used within an electrochemical process, the combined electrocatalytic process offers a whole new route to selectively tailor the conversion of biomass into fuels and useful chemicals, particularly through a process called hydrogenation. This project will develop a fundamental understanding of the mechanisms involved in these reactions to rationally design more efficient and selective biomass conversion processes. Educational activities offered by the project focus on the development of a series of short videos on renewables and nanotechnology that primarily targets middle and high school teachers, as they are in a unique position to generate excitement and curiosity for science in a large body of students.

The goal of this research is to explore new electrocatalysts and electrocatalytic pathways to hydrogenate biorenewable molecules into biofuels and chemicals in aqueous phase reaction medium at ambient temperatures. Bimetallic catalysts based on non-noble metals will be rationally designed to suppress the hydrogen evolution reaction on nanostructured carbon electrodes in order to increase hydrogen availability on the catalyst surface. The proposed research will seek to gain fundamental understanding of the electrocatalytic hydrogenation of C=C and C=O bonds in various compounds derived from biorenewable sources, particularly levulinic and muconic acid, in water under ambient conditions. This information will be then used to rationally design electrocatalysts with improved activity and selectivity towards target products in scalable electrolysis reactors. The interdisciplinary nature of this research will provide students at the graduate and undergraduate levels with training in electrochemical engineering, catalytic reactions, biorenewables, and biofuels. Outreach activities involve the professional development of K-12 teachers and the translation of their research experience into their curricula and classrooms, which will involve the development of short videos on broad challenges in energy, climate change, renewables, and nanotechnology.

Institution.Name: Iowa State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The electrification of chemical transformations, i.e. the use of electrons instead of heat to enhance reaction kinetics, provides new opportunities for the selective conversion of complex feedstock molecules. In contrast to thermochemical and thermocatalytic transformations that are solely governed by the transition states’ energetics and temperature, electrochemical and electrocatalytic reactions are also driven by electrode potential. This potential can be tuned to alter the energetics of the involved species and open new reaction pathways. The benefits are significant: target functionalities in molecules with multiple redox centers are converted selectively, challenging reactions proceed at room temperature under adiabatic conditions, reductive and oxidative reactions can be coupled to achieve energy-neutral processes. From a sustainability perspective, this also implies that new processes that favor the use of water as a green solvent, Earth-abundant metals as catalysts, and wind or sun as a source of renewable energy become possible.

This project investigated the aqueous-phase electrochemical hydrogenation of furanics and unsaturated diacids, two classes of biobased compounds with significant potential for use as biofuels and chemicals for the polymer industry. Our goal was to understand the mechanisms involved in the electrochemical and electrocatalytic hydrogenation of their unsaturated functionalities (C=O and C=C) and identify key relationships that govern selectivity for these transformations.

We demonstrated that biologically-produced cis,cis-muconic acid, a diunsaturated diacid, can be hydrogenated to either the monounsaturated compound trans-3-hexenedioic acid or the saturated product adipic acid with high selectivity. In the presence of a precious metal catalyst, the reaction follows a pathway similar to the thermocatalytic hydrogenation, with the exceptions that the reaction takes place under ambient conditions and hydrogen is produced in situ through splitting of the solvent water molecules. In the absence of a catalyst, the reaction produces trans-3-hexenedioic acid with high selectivity (>98% and 100% stereoselectivity) through electronation-protonation, a pathway specific to the electrochemical route. This transformation proceeds directly in the liquid phase, thereby allowing the reaction to also take place in complex media like fermentation broths, which presents significant technological advantages in terms of process integration and cost savings.

We have also thoroughly studied the pathways involved in the electrochemical reduction of carbonyl groups in biorenewable compounds. We have distinguished two distinct mechanisms taking place on metallic Cu electrodes in acidic electrolytes: electrocatalytic hydrogenation (ECH) and direct electroreduction. The contributions of each mechanism to the observed product distribution were elucidated by evaluating the requirement for direct chemical interactions with the electrode surface and the role of adsorbed hydrogen. Further analysis revealed that hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis products are generated by parallel ECH pathways. Understanding the underlying mechanisms enabled the manipulation of furfural reduction by rationally tuning the electrode potential, electrolyte pH, and furfural concentration to promote selective formation of important bio-based polymer precursors and fuels.

We have also studied the electrocatalytic hydrogenation (reduction) and oxidation of 5-(hydroxymethyl)furfural (HMF) to two monomers: 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)furan (BHMF) and 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid  (FDCA) in a paired electrolyzer. Low cell operation voltage and nearly doubled electron efficiency were obtained compared to the unpaired cell when coupling HMF reduction and oxidation in the same reactor.

In addition to advancing the electrosynthesis of biofuels and biorenewable chemicals, this project served as a platform to train 8 graduate students and 10 undergraduates. All the doctoral students who were involved in this project and who have graduated have found employment in engineering. Two of the undergraduates decided to pursue a doctoral degree as a result of the research experience provided through this grant. The co-PI also developed a new elective course on Electrochemical Engineering to educate both graduate and undergraduate students at Iowa State University on important concepts pertaining to energy storage, energy production, and electrochemical manufacturing.


Last Modified: 06/16/2020
Modified by: Jean-Philippe Tessonnier
